title: 106_hr816
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are included in income. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include unpaid child support payments as taxable income by treating them as amounts includible in gross income. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include unpaid child support payments as taxable income by treating them as amounts includible in gross income. Payments must meet specific requirements to qualify for a deduction under section 166(f). If a deduction under section 166(f) is claimed, the taxpayer must notify the individual who did not make payments of the amount of child support payments for the previous year that must be included in their gross income. If the address of the eligible taxpayer is unknown, the Secretary will send a notice if the address is available. If there is no known address, no income will be included in gross income for previous taxable years. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Subsequent payments included in gross income can be deducted in the year they are made. Definitions for 'applicable child support payments' and 'eligible taxpayer' are provided in section 166(f). SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers. Subsections (a) and (d) do not apply to these payments, and the taxpayer can deduct the amount of unpaid child support payments remaining at the end of the taxable year. The amendment to Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments up to $10,000 per child, provided their adjusted gross income does not exceed $50,000 for the taxable year. The amendment to Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments remaining unpaid as of the close of the taxable year equal to or greater than $500, and who meet the identification requirements. The term 'applicable child support payment' includes periodic fixed payments or medical payments for the eligible taxpayer's taxable year. The amendment allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments of $500 or more remaining unpaid by the end of the taxable year. This includes payments for medical or educational expenses required under a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. The amendment allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments of $500 or more remaining unpaid by the end of the taxable year, as long as at least half of the payments required to be paid to the eligible taxpayer during the 12-month period are delinquent. The amendment allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments of $500 or more remaining unpaid by the end of the taxable year, as long as at least half of the payments required to be paid to the taxpayer during the 12-month period are delinquent. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes amounts assigned to a State under section 408(a)(3) of the Social Security Act. The eligible taxpayer can deduct unpaid child support payments of $500 or more remaining unpaid by the end of the taxable year, as long as at least half of the payments required to be paid to the taxpayer during the 12-month period are delinquent. The taxpayer must include the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of each child and the individual required to make the child support payments on the tax return claiming the deduction. In case of failure to provide information, eligible taxpayer can certify unknown information. Cost-of-living adjustments increase specified amounts annually. The eligible taxpayer can certify unknown information in case of failure to provide it. Cost-of-living adjustments increase specified amounts annually. Subsequent payments with deductions allowed under paragraph (1) will be included in gross income for the taxable year in which paid, except if the right to receive such amount is assigned to a State. For tax purposes, a support instrument includes a divorce decree, separation agreement, or court order for child support payments. Payments made under these instruments are taxable unless assigned to a State. The amendment allows for a deduction for unpaid child support payments under the tax code. This includes applicable child support payments as defined in subsection (f). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5 of the Act states that net revenues received will be used solely to retire the US public debt, regardless of other laws.
